{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:22:27.519

}}

{{TranscriptBlock

    | text      = remarried a woman half a century younger than him. Accusations of malfeasance were flying

{{TranscriptBlock

    | timestamp = 00:22:36.240
    | text      = around him all over the place, so it only makes sense that an enterprising member of
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:22:40.319
    | text      = that group would see it as the right time to start their own thing, and that's exactly
}}

{{TranscriptBlock

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:22:45.839
    | text      = So, when Smith started his Church of God Evangelistic Association, he didn't stray too far from some

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:22:55.839
    | text      = was Armstrong's teachings about British Israelism, which might strike you as a foreign concept.

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:23:03.920
    | text      = No. No, no, no, because of course I would put together Israel and Britain. Those two
}}

{{TranscriptBlock

    | text      = things seem so closely related to me in my theological history.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:23:16.160
    | text      = I guess you can kind of guess what it is from those two words, sort of.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:23:20.000
    | text      = White Jews. White people are the white people.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:23:22.640
    | text      = You're not far off. The subject of British Israelism is a really complicated thing, and

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

{{TranscriptBlock

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:23:36.000

{{TranscriptBlock

{{TranscriptBlock

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:23:49.920
    | text      = Proponents of the theory point to Bible stories about Jacob, later to be renamed Israel, who
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:23:54.960
    | text      = had twelve sons, each of whom gave birth to their own tribes, the twelve tribes of Israel.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:23:59.839
    | text      = When Solomon died, only two of these tribes, those of Judah and Benjamin, would accept
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:24:04.559
    | text      = the rule of Solomon's son, Rehoboam. Rehoboam was a shitty and cruel leader, and his ascent
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:24:09.920
    | text      = to the throne would result in what amounted to a civil war. These two tribes that sided
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:24:14.400
    | text      = with him became the Southern Kingdom, or the Kingdom of Judah, and the ten other tribes
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:24:18.480
    | text      = were the Northern Kingdom, or the Kingdom of Israel. In the 720s BCE, the Assyrians
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:24:23.920
    | text      = invaded and sent all those tribes in the Southern Kingdom into exile, and as the story goes,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:24:30.559
    | text      = the ten tribes became lost.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:24:32.240
    | text      = However, archaeology, anthropology, and historical records do not agree with this simplistic
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:24:36.960
    | text      = and clear-cut version of these tribes just getting lost to history. Many members of these
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:24:41.839
    | text      = tribes fled back to the Southern Kingdom and reabsorbed into that population. Others were
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:24:46.720
    | text      = taken back to Assyria and Medea, where they were assimilated into those cultures.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:24:50.559
    | text      = Yeah, that makes sense. It's not like it was a Walmart and they just got lost in there,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:24:55.440
    | text      = never to be seen from again.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:24:57.440
    | text      = Yeah. In 586 BCE, Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon attacked the Southern Kingdom and the population
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:03.039
    | text      = was exiled.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:03.839
    | text      = Shout out to Nebi.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:05.039
    | text      = This population of the Southern Kingdom, Judah, was by that point constituted of the two tribes
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:10.640
    | text      = who stayed loyal to Rehoboam, as well as many of the members of the Northern Kingdom who
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:14.240
    | text      = had fled south 140 years prior, who had integrated by that point.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:18.079
    | text      = Right, of course.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:18.960
    | text      = By the time the exiled Israelites returned to Jerusalem to rebuild the kingdom, their
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:23.599
    | text      = identity was largely unified. The people are real, the struggles are real, the heritage
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:29.599
    | text      = is real, but the idea that these tribes got lost is seen by most scholars as more myth
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:34.480
    | text      = than history. The consensus opinion is that between the Assyrian invasion of the Northern
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:39.279
    | text      = Kingdom and the Babylonian invasion of the Southern Kingdom, most of the members of these
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:43.440
    | text      = tribes had become integrated into the larger identity of the Kingdom of Judah, or into
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:48.079
    | text      = the places where they had ended up, like Assyria.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:50.720
    | text      = Yeah. Well, as a national history, it makes sense to put that myth together because that
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:56.400
    | text      = way you almost immediately remove the tribal identity of those, quote, lost tribes, you
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:02.960
    | text      = know?
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:03.279
    | text      = Right.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:03.839
    | text      = If you are in one of those lost tribes and you came back, you're no longer in that lost
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:08.640
    | text      = tribe, you're in ours. So you create the myth that they're lost as opposed to like, they
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:19.200
    | text      = of thing, in order to strengthen your own national identity.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:22.319
    | text      = So flash forward to more modern days. For centuries, legends about the lost tribes had

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

    | text      = six days of the week and stops on Shabbat when the 10 tribes are forbidden to travel.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:41.119
    | text      = Poetic explanations abounded for why no one had found the tribes, even though people were
}}

{{TranscriptBlock

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:46.640

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

}}

{{TranscriptBlock

    | text      = this magical river that stops only on the time when they can't cross it.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

    | text      = All right. I like that, though. I enjoy that image in my head. It's a fun image.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:03.759
    | text      = Then in 1590, a book called The Ten Lost Tribes was published. The book gave the first
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:08.960
    | text      = voice to the theory that groups like the Celts, the Germans, the Scandinavians, they
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:13.440
    | text      = were in fact the tribes of Israel that had gotten lost. While the theory didn't go
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:17.839
    | text      = mega-viral, it did gain a little bit of traction early on, and here's where one of the most
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:21.839
    | text      = important distinctions comes into play.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:24.240
    | text      = In the 1600s, as this idea began to spread a little bit in Britain, it was not explicitly
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:29.680
    | text      = anti-Semitic. The proponents of this theory believed that the people who were Jewish were
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

    | text      = the descendants of the tribes of Judah and that the white Anglo-Saxons were the ten
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:38.640
    | text      = tribes that got lost, so they were all Israelites.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:41.839
    | text      = It could definitely be described as co-opting, but at that point in history, the ideas were
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:46.079
    | text      = not being spread to deny Jewish people their heritage or to demonize them. There were plenty
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:50.559
    | text      = of other problems with the theory back then, which we'll get into later, but anti-Semitism
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:54.480
    | text      = was not one of them.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:55.519
    | text      = So it was just kind of one of those, like, why is it, it's almost fitting together why
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:28:00.880
    | text      = we believe in our version of Christianity with why are we completely different people?
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:28:06.720
    | text      = So you kind of say, well, now we're also Jews, so that makes more sense in that context?
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:28:13.119
    | text      = There's probably a little piece of it that's that, but I think that there's a much larger
}}

{{TranscriptBlock

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

    | text      = Okay.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

    | text      = I think there's some timing issues.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:28:20.160
    | text      = All right.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:28:21.039
    | text      = So these notions existed in small pockets for a long time, finally reaching their peak
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:28:25.279
    | text      = in the late 1800s and into the early 1900s. In the early 1900s, as these theories began
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:28:31.839
    | text      = to take hold in the United States, that is the point where things got ugly. Here's the
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:28:36.319
    | text      = final caveat I will give on the matter. There are apparently still some churches that exist
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:28:41.440
    | text      = that believe in British Israelism that don't hate Jewish people, but they are the exception,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

    | text      = Yeah.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:28:48.480
    | text      = In the 1920s in the United States, British Israel beliefs were co-opted by outright

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:28:58.000

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

{{TranscriptBlock

{{TranscriptBlock

}}

{{TranscriptBlock

    | text      = model popularized by Louis Beam, who was an adherent of Christian Identity.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:29:26.319
    | text      = God damn it.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:29:28.000
    | text      = Christian Identity's fingerprints are all over the history of the people behind right-wing
}}

{{TranscriptBlock

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:29:42.559
    | text      = Lincoln Rockwell.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:29:44.079
    | text      = The key difference between British Israelism in the 1600s in Britain and the 1900s in America
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:29:50.000
    | text      = is that whereas the prior believed that Jews were also descendants of Israel, the latter
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:29:55.359
    | text      = did not. As the British Israelism beliefs became co-opted by the Christian Identity
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:30:00.559
    | text      = movement, the narrative changed. No longer was the theory just that white people were
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:30:05.359
    | text      = also Israelites, it was now that they were the only true Israelites, and that a vast
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:30:10.400
    | text      = majority of the people who think they're Jewish are imposters.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:30:14.319
    | text      = Okay, well, stop that, all of you. All of you? What? No! That's insane!
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:30:20.319
    | text      = It's wild stuff. But it underpins a ton of these right-wing movements. It's insidious
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:30:28.640
    | text      = and it's very difficult to track how many people or what people are into, because no
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:30:35.279
    | text      = one's like, hey, I'm a Christian Identity preacher, or at least most don't. But their
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:30:40.000
    | text      = ideas can be very clearly traced a lot of the time, and that's one of the things that
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:30:44.880
    | text      = is really murky and really hard about this world.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:30:47.039
    | text      = It's amazing to me how far these people go to justify their bigotry. It all starts from
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:30:54.400
    | text      = you think white people are the best, and then you have to create these fantastical situations
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:00.319
    | text      = where you're like, no, it's okay, I think white people are the best.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:04.480
    | text      = I think a lot of it can be traced to the idea of wanting to retain a self-image of being
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:12.079
    | text      = Christian and upholding Christian ideas.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:14.480
    | text      = While at the same time hating people, even though Christ would be against them.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:18.160
    | text      = Finding a way to rationalize and hold those two positions simultaneously, I think, is
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:22.720
    | text      = a large part of people who buy into the...
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:25.039
    | text      = It's so true.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:25.200
    | text      = Well, but it also is much easier than maybe giving up whatever security you feel in your
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:32.799
    | text      = supremacy here.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:33.440
    | text      = Yeah, that's true.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:34.079
    | text      = I don't know. Anyway, some Christian Identity folks swing for the fences and argue that
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:38.880
    | text      = Jews are literally descended from the devil.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:41.519
    | text      = Okay.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:42.880
    | text      = But the more mainline position is that the Anglo-Saxons, as the tribes that got lost,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock

    | timestamp = 00:31:47.519
    | text      = carry out the pure bloodline. The descendants of the tribe of Judah, though they believe
}}

{{TranscriptBlock

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

    | text      = Their ancestors were actually a population of Turks who converted to Judaism as part

{{TranscriptBlock

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

    | text      = Oh, boy.

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:14.400
    | text      = The answer goes back to Genesis 25 and the story of Jacob and Esau.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:18.160
    | text      = Esau was Isaac's firstborn son, and as such he was entitled to a larger share of the inheritance
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:24.000
    | text      = and all the rights of lineage that come along with being recognized as the firstborn.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:28.240
    | text      = The name for this in the Bible is birthright.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:31.839
    | text      = Genesis 25 tells the story of Esau returning home very hungry from work and asking Jacob

{{TranscriptBlock
